author: Dennis Knight
title: Riley revs it up in Memorial Day win
text:
Photos Photo courtesy of Memorial Day Irvin Riley of Memorial Day is the Savannah Morning News player of the week for Oct. 6 By Dennis Knight Memorial Day’s Irvin Riley had the best game of his high school career Thursday night — rushing for 209 yards and four touchdowns, but it was a 53-yard scoring reception that stood out in his mind in a win at Robert Toombs Christian Academy.
Riley caught a short pass from Adrian Smith and turned it into a memorable touchdown.
“I caught it in the right flat and got a great block from Delvechio (Powell),” Riley said. “I ran over one defender and another came from the side and tried to shoulder tackle me, but I got away, and after that it was a foot race.”
Riley added touchdown runs of 53, 3, 47 and 14 yards as Memorial Day beat the Crusaders 42-21 on a rainy night in Lyons. Riley earned Savannah Morning News player of the week honors for his effort.
“That was the most yards I have ever run for,” said Riley, who has 583 yards rushing, 201 yards receiving and 11 total touchdowns this season. “Our guys did a great job blocking up front, and our backs were leading me through the holes to open things up.”
Memorial Day coach Michael Thompson said keeping a close eye on Riley in practice helped lead to the breakout performance.
“He’s had a turf toe that has been hurting him in the past few weeks,” Thompson said. “So we told him not to make any cuts and limited him in practice last week, and it paid off. Irvin is a runner who is going to take what a defense gives him. He can run people over or run past them — he’s an impressive back.
The 5-foot-9, 185-pound senior is receiving recruiting interest from schools such as Army, Kennesaw State and Georgia State.
Last season, Riley was an important part of the Blue Thunder offense — rushing for 1,036 yards and scoring 13 touchdowns as Memorial Day beat Piedmont Academy to win the GISA Class AA state championship. Thursday’s win was the second straight for the Blue Thunder (3-4 overall, 1-0 in Region 2-AA). Memorial Day has a bye week before an important region matchup with First Presbyterian in its homecoming game at Garden City Stadium on Oct. 17.
“We have some young guys, but I think we are starting to mature as a team,” Riley said. “We’re starting to play with a different level of intensity.”
Other top performances:
Calvin Turner, New Hampstead — The junior threw for 125 yards and a touchdown, rushed for 55 yards and a score and caught a 50-yard touchdown pass from Jalen De La Fuente in the Phoenix’s win over Glascock County.
Sal Calderon, Calvary Day — The junior rushed for 162 yards and two touchdowns and passed for 55 yards in the Cavaliers’ win over Jenkins County.
Andre Jackson, Savannah High — The senior rushed for 109 yards and a touchdown in the Blue Jackets’ win over Johnson.
Melvin Smalls Jr., Jenkins — Rushed for 102 yards and a pair of touchdowns in a win over Islands.
Wesley Kennedy, Benedictine — The junior rushed for 91 yards and a pair of touchdowns in the Cadets’ win over Wayne County.
Patrick Brown, South Effingham — The senior rushed for 123 yards and a touchdown and had 209 yards of total offense in the Mustangs’ win over Brunswick.
Ameen Stevens, Jenkins — The sophomore rushed for 101 yards and two scores in the Warriors’ win over Islands.
Winston Wright, Memorial Day — The freshman had a pair of interceptions in a win over Robert Toombs Christian.
Tyler Pullum, South Effingham — The senior quarterback was 10 of 14 for 151 yards with touchdown passes to T.J. Williams and Marcus Boyd in the Mustangs’ win over Brunswick.
